_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Executive Summary



1.1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Risk Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site makes use of the Clayton County Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 



1.2.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 1361 Southern Road, Morrow, Georgia. The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.

The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia. One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce.  



1.3.    Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the volume of the single High Pressure Receiver (a maximum of (12,196 lbs) .  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 1.2 miles.

The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia from a ruptured evaporator coil caused by thermal expansion due to double blocking of the line.  The largest-condenser coils (EC-1 and EC-2) were assumed and a volume of 2,357 lbs of ammonia were used for release calculations.  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario even though line lockout/tagout

(an administrative control) exists.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.1 mile.



1.4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  

This includes:

*    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction

        and modification

*    Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) at least once every five years 

        using accurate Process Safety Information

*    Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA

*    Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel  

*    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component 

        manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot

        work permit programs

*    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols

*    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system

The detailed Ammonia System Release Prevention Program is contained in a supporting document (revised and updated May, 2015) which is maintained at the site Safety Office.



1.5.    Five Year Accident History

Between June, 2010 (the previous revalidation of the site program) and the present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage.



1.6.    Emergency Response Program

Fresh Express has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies.  The plan is maintained at the site Safety Office and reviewed

annually.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases. 

The site has an Ammonia Emergency Response Team trained to use the Incident Command System organizational framework.  This is also described in detail in the planning document.



1.7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the Revalidation Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) conducted on May 08, 2015 the following adjustments are planned to ensure continued safe operations:

        in the cooling water system for condensers.     Fernando Villasenor  12/30/2015

        Operator training; Rounds

        The ice build-up causes tube leaks/ruptures.    

        Daily rounds, Operator training, SOPs.

        by HVAC equipment. Implement procedure to

        deactivate HVAC for office areas.

        the water evaporates or leaks                   Fernando Villasenor   07/31/2015

        PM program; rounds; Install sensor and alarm to

        notify of low water level.
